metadata.title: Fracture, Acromion
anatomical location body part affected: Superior shoulder suspensory complex (SSSC), also referred to as the shoulder girdle complex or shoulder joint
description: The acromion is a superior bony process on the scapula. A continuation of the scapular spine, the acromion projects laterally and then hooks over the anterior aspect of the humeral head. The acromion articulates with the clavicle to form the acromioclavicular (AC) joint. Muscular attachments are the deltoid and trapezius. Ligamentous attachments are the acromioclavicular and coracoacromial. The acromion is one component of the SSSC, also referred to as the shoulder girdle complex

ICD-10 codes.S42.7: multiple fractures of clavicle, scapula and humerus
ICD-10 codes.S42.12: fracture of acromial process (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Major signs and symptoms are pain, point tenderness, swelling, deformity, and restricted ROM with crepitus at the fracture site at the base of the acromion
Patient may support the injured arm at the side with the contralateral arm
Glenohumeral joint and scapular muscle weakness Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Avoid activities that reproduce crepitus or movement at the fracture site
Request specific guidelines from the referring physician regarding fracture stability, precautions for mobilization, and expected outcome
Request preoperative and postoperative protocol from physician/surgeon
It is important to respect the patient’s subjective complaints of pain during evaluation
Contact physician immediately if examination reveals any neurovascular damage
Neural tension tests and joint accessory motion testing should be deferred until radiographic evidence of fracture healing is shown

causes: Direct and/or high-energy  trauma from an external force to the superior aspect of theshoulder (e.g., motor vehicle accident, fall)
Acromion stress fractures, although extremely rare, have also been reported with rotatorcufftear arthropathy and superior migration of the head of the humerus(3)

Iatrogenic fractures of the acromion–Aggressive arthroscopic subacromial decompression procedures can weaken thebone and may result in a fracture when force is applied (e.g., during ADLs orrehabilitation)(1)–Transacromial portal surgical procedure utilized by some surgeons to gain access tothe superior glenoid labrum for arthroscopic fixation of a superior labrum anterior andposterior (SLAP) lesion may compromise acromial integrity by as much as 85%(3)–Postoperative complication of a reverse shoulder arthroplasty(8,9)-Based on a systematic review, acromial and/or scapular fractures occur at a rate of2.8% after reverse shoulder arthroplasty. Most commonly, acromial fractures postreverse shoulder arthroplasty were associated with inflammatory arthritis and massiverotator cuff tears(11)
pathogenesis: Acromion fractures have been classified by Kuhn et al.(4) into 5 distinct types–Type I fractures are minimally displaced–Type IA are avulsion fractures and heal rapidly–Type IB fractures result from direct trauma to the extremity and are minimally displaced. Most heal with nonoperativetreatment–Type II fractures are displaced laterally, superiorly, or anteriorly and do not reduce the subacromial space. The majorityare pain free with full motion after 6 weeks of nonoperative treatment–Type III fractures displace the acromion inferiorly, reducing the subacromial space. Patients in this group usually havesustained significant trauma to the involved extremity. Pain and limited ROM secondary to impingement of the rotatorcuff indicate early surgical intervention to lift and fixate the fractured and displaced acromion(2)

The SSSC includes the glenoid process, the coracoid process, the coracoacromial ligament, the distal end of the clavicle,the acromioclavicular joint, and the acromion process. A single failure in the SSSC causes a stable injury. Failure in twoor more places in the SSSC (such as the clavicle and a displaced scapular neck fracture) causes instability or a “floatingshoulder”(1)
risk factors: Traumatic fractures of the acromion are rare. They occur predominantly in males aged 25–45  years involved in a sportscollision (such as in hockey or football), a motor vehicle accident, trauma to the shoulder blade, or a high-speed  fall (suchas in alpine skiing)(3)
Nontraumatic fractures, which are even more rare, may be seen in older adults with rotator cuff tendinopathy and/orosteoporotic changes(3)

Three morphologically distinct types of acromia have been described (Bigliani classification).(6) Type 3 has a reportedhigher incidence of acromial stress fractures, iatrogenic fractures, and rotator cuff tears(6)–Type 1 – flat acromial undersurface that extends away from humeral head–Type 2 – curved–Type 3 – acromial thickness less than 8 mm; higher risk for acromial fractures during arthroscopic or open decompressionsurgery

Os acromiale is a congenital abnormality in which the ossification centers of the acromion fail to fuse. The anterior os iscartilaginous until 15–16  years of age, when the ossification centers appear. Normal fusion occurs by age 25–In 2% to 8% of the general population, there is a nonunion resulting in altered glenohumeral (GH) joint articulation–Os acromiale can become symptomatic after age 40 with a diagnosis of impingement syndrome and has been implicatedas a cause of rotator cuff tears–Os acromiale can be confused with an acromial fracture(3)

overall contraindications precautions: Carefully follow physician’s orders and parameters
Clinicians should suspect the presence of associated injuries in patients who have sustained high-velocity  or direct trauma
Strengthening exercises are generally not allowed until radiographic evidence of fracture healing is shown
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: What led to the patient’s injury and/or shoulder pain? A fall? Was there trauma to the shoulder and any concomitant injuries? When did the injury occur? Is the fracture located on the patient’s dominant upper extremity?

course of treatment.medical management: Ask about the patient’s past and current medical management. If the patient required surgery, when did this occur? How has the pain responded to treatments? Displaced acromion fractures may be managed arthroscopically or with open reduction and internal fixation
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? Are they effectively controlling the symptoms? Is patient taking NSAIDs or narcotic analgesics?
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for this condition are the following:
Radiographs: Standard anteroposterior, as well as axillary, 30° caudal tilt, and outlet views of both shoulders
CT scan may be needed to determine the displacement of the fracture to assess for surgical stabilization
MRI can be helpful for identifying stress fractures(7)
EMG can be performed beginning 3 weeks after injury in patients with a scapular fracture and a brachial plexus injury
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Movement of the arm is usually painful, thus requiring the use of a sling to allow union of the fracture
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night. Patient will usually be unable to sleep on the injured side. Does the patient use a pillow under his or her arm for support?
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/ or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to a physician (e.g., brachial plexus symptoms, neurovascular symptoms, rib pain with breathing) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes __ No __ -If Yes, describe __________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Any history of previous fractures? Shoulder injuries? Any history of cervical or thoracic spine pathology?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask the patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, psychiatric disorders, rheumatoid arthritis, osteoporosis, and other relevant orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs, herbal supplements)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in recreational or competitive sports? Inquire about the degree of impact the injury is having on work or leisure activities. Does patient use  injured upper extremity repeatedly above shoulder height at home, work, and recreational activities? Does the patient drive?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: The patient may have limited function if dominant arm is affected. Does the patient use an assistive device for ambulation or any adaptive equipment for ADLs?
social and occupational history.living environment: With whom does patient live (children, spouse)? Will that person be able to assist patient with upper extremity ADLs, driving, if needed? Identify if there are barriers to independence in home and community

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.)  Evaluation procedures should be modified according to patient’s age, diagnosis, and any unique circumstances such as a recent injury
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Evaluate for proper fit of the upper extremity sling. Educate the patient and/or caregiver as to correct placement. Are the wrist and hand free to use while wearing the sling?
relevant tests and measures.balance: Balance may be compromised while wearing the shoulder sling; assess as indicated, using the Berg Balance Scale, especially if fracture was secondary to a fall
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess brachial and radial pulses for bilateral symmetryAssess neural dynamic testing of the brachial plexus if ROM is not contraindicated. Upper limb neural tension tests may be contraindicated in the acute stages of the injuryComplete a functional assessment
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Complete a gait assessment; observe for reduced arm swing post discharge of immobilizer. If fracture is secondary to a fall, assess safety with ambulation; may use Dynamic Gait Index (DGI) or Timed Up and Go (TUG) test for objective measuresAssessment of glenohumeral, acromioclavicular, and sternoclavicular joint mobility and stability may need to be delayed until union of the fracture has occurred. Assess for subacromial impingement once fracture has healed
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Defer strength testing until fracture is healed
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess unsupported position of shoulder, scapula, and cervical spine in sitting and standing. Is there scapular winging? A low shoulder may indicate ligamentous disruption and/or rotator cuff weakness
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess passive ROM (PROM) of shoulder, elbow, and wrist in pain-free  range according to physician’s restrictions on ROM. Assess active ROM (AROM) of the uninvolved upper extremity. AROM of involved extremity may be deferred until fracture is healed
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess bilateral triceps, biceps, and brachioradialis deep-tendon  reflexes as permitted by physicianAssess ability to dress and undress. Does the patient require assistance with self-care?  Assess ability to perform work/leisure activities specific to patient’s needs
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Assess bilateral upper extremities for sensation to touch and cold and warm temperatures. Note any asymmetry
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Patient-reported outcomes for upper limb function include –Upper Extremity Functional Index (UEFI) –Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) Outcome Measure
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: If the patient has sustained a traumatic brain injury or concussion in addition to the acromion fracture, assess and instruct appropriately

cryotherapy contraindications: Contraindications -Over the trunk or heart region in patients with demand-type  pacemakers and implantable cardioverter defibrillators (ICDs) -Over the pelvic, abdominal, lumbar, or hip region of a pregnant woman -Over the carotid bodies -Over the phrenic nerve, eyes, or gonads -Over areas of known peripheral vascular disease -Over areas of active osteomyelitis -Over areas of hemorrhage
cryotherapy precautions: Precautions -With patients without intact sensation -With patients who cannot communicate -With patients with compromised mental ability -With cardiac dysfunction (uncontrolled hypertension or hypotension, irregular heartbeat) -Over active or previous neoplasms -With electrodes -Over compromised skin, unless treating wound specifically  -Over tissues that are vulnerable to hemorrhage -Cervical region in patients with history of stroke or seizures -Do not use within 5 yards of diathermy units or other source of electromagnetic radiation
contraindications precautions: Over an area of peripheral vascular disease
Over an area of poor sensation
In the very young and the very old
Persons with an aversion to cold
Over areas with a lack of intact thermal sensation
Over areas of vascular insufficiency or vascular disease
Over areas of recent hemorrhage or potential hemorrhage
Over infected areas where infection may spread
Over areas where liniments or heat rubs have recently been applied
In any situation deemed unreliable by the practitioner
other: Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment
Avoid activities that reproduce crepitus over the fracture site
Avoid forceful ROM above 90°of elevation if patient is experiencing shoulder impingement pain
Active exercises that use the trapezius and deltoid muscles (insert on the acromion) should be postponed until radiographic evidence of union is obtained
Evidence is lacking to determine the effectiveness of electromechanical modalities for acromion fracture rehabilitation

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and physician orders. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

Electrotherapy  contraindications/precautions (in some cases,  when approved by the treating physician , electrotherapy may be used under some of the circumstances listed below when benefits outweigh the perceived risk)(5)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Diagnosis/need for treatment Physical therapy is indicated for pain management and restoration of upper extremity ROM, strength, and function. Patient education in a home program should be taught to complement supervised rehabilitation –Conservative treatment of nondisplaced fractures begins with immobilization of the scapula, shoulder, and arm in a sling. Early progressive ROM will help to avoid glenohumeral joint stiffness(3) –Most scapular fractures (90%) have little or no displacement and will heal within 6–8 weeks. Full recovery of function may take several months(2) –Postoperatively, protocols vary depending on the type of fixation device used and physician protocol. Generally, the patient is immobilized in an abduction brace for 6 weeks. Physical therapy PROM is started at 4 weeks; AROM at 8–10 weeks(2)
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Os acromiale Acromioclavicular osteolysis Fracture of distal end clavicle Glenohumeral fracture Glenohumeral dislocation Rotator cuff tear Acromioclavicular separation Labral tear Rib fracture Shoulder contusion Pneumothorax Brachial plexus injury
treatment summary: Follow specific physician protocols, whether nonsurgical or postsurgical, due to variations in management of acromion fracture

Acromion fractures are often managed with conservative treatment; surgery is recommended to individuals who show signs of impingement and evidence of decreased subacromial space(10) –With conservative treatment, the nonunion rate is relatively high. Therapists should be aware that nonunion is not always painful and it does not limit reasonable shoulder activity, especially in less active individuals. Surgical stabilization may be more suitable for active individuals who are more likely to need revision of symptomatic nonunions(12)

There is currently a void in the literature regarding physical therapy treatment intervention for acromion fractures . desired outcomes: Relief of pain–V AS for pain
Full pain-free  shoulder ROM–ROM, goniometry–Flexibility testing
Minimal tenderness at acromion fracture site
Restored shoulder and upper extremity strength–Manual muscle test–Grip strength dynamometry
Independent in ADLs and return to work/sport–Functional outcome measures: UEFI or DASH Outcome Measure–Balance tests: Berg Balance Scale–Gait assessment: TUG test, Dynamic Gait Index

maintenance or prevention: Continue home exercise program to maintain and/or improve ROM and strength needed for ADLs, work, or sport
In populations most at risk for falls, follow fall-prevention  recommendations
